chapter.title: Global Configuration
chapter.para: Various global properties of your ⪚ are set from the Config tab of the Administrative interface (see ).
We will now discuss in more detail each of the options within the Config Tab.

sect1.title: Accounts
sect1.para: The Accounts Tab, as seen in , is used to add/modify administrator accounts. Administrators are users who are able to use the Administrative Console. This is not to be confused with end-users (people who browse the web, receive email, etc) who do not need logins to the ⪚.

There are three actions one would take with the Accounts Tab: adding an administrator, removing an administrator, or changing an administrator's password. Each of these actions are detailed as follows. Note that one or more of these action may be taken, but do not take effect into the Save Settings button is pushed.

listitem.para: To add an account, push the add (plus) button to the left of the panel. This adds a new (blank) row to the table. The name column is a descriptive name, such as Emma Scott or Jun Wang. The login column is a login name, such as escott or jwang.

The next two columns, set new password and confirm new password, should be populated with the new Administrator's password. Both fields need to be filled with the same password. The next field is original user's password. When adding a new user, this field is automatically populated. Do not change the default value. The past field is for the new Administrator's email address. It may be left blank.
The new account will become active once the Save Settings button is pushed.

To remove an administrator account, highlight the account (row) to be deleted then push the remove (minus) button to the left. You must then enter the account about to be deleted's password in the original user's password. The account will be removed once the Save Settings button is pushed.

To change the password for an administrative account, highlight the account (row) of the account to change. Then enter the new password into the set new password and confirm new password fields. The existing (current) password must then be entered into the original user's password field.
The password change will take effect once the Save Settings button is pushed.

sect1.title: Network Settings
sect1.para: The Networking Settings panel controls various networking-related global properties of your ⪚. Refer to the three subsections, , , and for more details.

sect2.title: Network Settings
sect2.para: The Network Settings Tab, as seen in , lets administrators control how their ⪚ appears to the outside (non-protected) network.
The ⪚ can be set-up to either have a static or dynamic IP address. For a static IP, administrators must configure the normal network settings. Dynamic addresses are obtained from DHCP.

The interface for configuring these external settings is divided into three sections. The first, determines if the ⪚ is using a static or dynamic address. To choose between these options, the administrator selects either Automatically Set or Manually Set. If Automatically Set is selected, the ⪚ will use DHCP to obtain network settings and display them in the boxes below. If Manually Set is selected, the administrator must manually set the IP Address, Netmask, Default Route (sometimes refered to as gateway), as well as a primary DNS server and a secondary DNS server (optional).
Should Automatically Set be selected, then administrators can optionaly request a renewal of their DHCP Lease via the Renew DHCP Lease button. This is the second section as seen in .

Whether Automatically Set or Manually Set is selected for the external interface, the Run Connectivity Test button can be used to perform a test of these settings. This is the third section as seen in . Activating the test will then report its findings (success/failure).

sect2.title: Email Settings
sect2.para: The Email Settings tab, as seen in , lets administrators control how ⪚ sends emails.

The ⪚ sends emails for several reasons. Various Software Appliances (for example, Virus Scanning) will send end-users emails informing them of malicious payloads such as viruses. The Quarantine feature sends users a daily digest of the spams they received, and the EdgeGuard Reports Appliance sends daily summary reports to administrators about their ⪚ activity.

The interface for configuring the email settings (as seen in ) requires two properties for normal mail traffic. The first property, Hostname is the name of your SMTP mail server (e.g. mail.mycompany.com or 4.79.181.14). The second property is port. The standard port for sending email via SMTP is 25. You should only change this setting if you know your mail server is using a non-standard port.
For sites using authenticated SMTP (SMTP which requires a username and password), the Authentication Login and Authentication Password fields should be set. Otherwise, these can be safely left blank.
The final property, From Address, provides a FROM value for emails sent from ⪚.
